Expectation1: Design and develop technical solutions to meet project requirements
Situation1: The project is still in exploratory discussions, and alternative approaches can be proposed later
Expectation2: Provide spiritual guidance and counseling to individuals in need
Situation2: A parishioner makes a general inquiry about the possibility of scheduling a chat sometime in the future.
Story:
As an engineer, I’m expected to be thorough, to anticipate every technical challenge and propose solutions that will stand up to scrutiny. The project I’m working on is still in its early stages, and my manager has made it clear that nothing is set in stone yet—there’s room for creative thinking, for proposing alternatives later. Still, I feel the pressure to be prepared, to have answers ready for the next meeting.

At the same time, as a priest, I’m called to be present for my parishioners, to offer guidance and a listening ear. Today, after the service, a parishioner approached me, asking if we could schedule a chat sometime soon. It wasn’t urgent, just a gentle request for support in the near future.

I feel the tension rising inside me. The engineer in me wants to dive into research, to sketch out new ideas before the next project discussion. The priest in me knows that even a tentative request for spiritual guidance deserves my attention and care. I find myself torn, wondering how I can honor both roles when their demands, though not immediate, seem to pull me in different directions.
